newsitem.title: SRI LANKA: Bogala makes profit on better labour ties.
newsitem.headline: Bogala makes profit on better labour ties.

text.p: Bogala Graphite Lanka Ltd has made a profit for the first time since 1992, helped by improving labour relations, the company's chairman said on Monday.
New markets in India, Pakistan and South Korea also helped boost the bottomline, U.N. Jinasena told Reuters.
The company said earlier on Monday its net profit for nine months to December 31, 1996, was 17.59 million rupees, against a loss of 41.43 million rupees in the year-earlier period.
Bogala, which owns high-grade graphite mines, was partly privatised in 1992 when the government sold 49 percent of its 27.96 million shares to the public and the employees.
"The company fell into decay soon after privatisation due to a breakdown in labour relations, weak management and poor marketing," Jinasena said.

He said better relations with the firm's employees had improved productivity and he forecast output rising to an estimated 5,500 tonnes of graphite in the year ending March 31, 1997, from an average of 4,000 tonnes a year in the previous three years.
He said profitability was expected to improve further once Bogala rehabilitates two mines.
Bogala shares were last traded unchanged at 6.50 rupees on Monday.
